page.title: 01PENTIR
page.content: Only small villages and hamlets occur. Pentir is centrally situated with an inn and a post office to justify it naming the block. The landscape is dominated by hummocky terrain of the Menair Platform, the geologists name for a wild feature at an average height of about 100m and a width here around 5km, that occurs in this area as an inner coastal band around the Snowdonia hills. Land use is a mixture of improved grassland livestock farming, concentrated on the drier sand and gravel hummocks, with intervening areas of poorly drained rough pasture and a scatter of woods, mainly conifer plantings. Small quarries work the gravel and sand in a minor way. In the southwest, the platform ends in steep slopes of the Snowdonian foothills at Moel y Ci, where there is a transition from
